title: Unbalanced Mach-Zehnder Interferometer with Path Length Control
description: Demonstrates quantum interference using asymmetric arm lengths and variable delay for fringe visibility control.
physics_explanation: Coherent laser light splits into superposition state at input beam splitter, creating |ψ⟩ = (|upper⟩ + |lower⟩)/√2. The asymmetric path design with longer lower arm and variable delay stage allows precise control of relative phase φ between arms. At recombination, interference produces output intensities I₁,₂ = I₀(1 ± cos(φ))/2, demonstrating wave-particle duality and phase-dependent quantum interference.

component_justifications.HeNe Laser: Provides stable, coherent 632.8nm light with sufficient coherence length for the unequal arm lengths in this asymmetric design
component_justifications.Input BS: 50:50 cube beam splitter creates equal amplitude superposition of photon being in upper and lower interferometer arms
component_justifications.Upper Mirror: Redirects upper arm beam toward delay stage, creating the shorter interferometer path
component_justifications.Delay Stage: Motorized translation stage provides precise control of optical path difference between arms for phase tuning and fringe scanning
component_justifications.Lower Mirror 1: First mirror in extended lower arm path, creating the longer baseline for increased sensitivity
component_justifications.Lower Mirror 2: Second mirror completing the extended lower arm geometry before recombination
component_justifications.Output BS: Recombines the two interferometer arms, enabling quantum interference between the path amplitudes
component_justifications.Detector 1: Measures transmitted interference output, showing complementary fringes to reflected output
component_justifications.Detector 2: Measures reflected interference output, demonstrating conservation of photon probability between ports

expected_outcome: Sinusoidal interference fringes as delay stage scans, with complementary intensity oscillations at both detectors and fringe visibility approaching unity for good alignment.
